Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2009 09:01AM fulloflife wrote: all should call the whitehouse---they keep making 'preventative medicine' an issue but if insurance companies won't cover the tests to prevent disease then the WH should take issue with that, otherwise they should stop campaigning about preventative medicine
Posts.Title: Insurance company will not cover my MRI blas dlb823

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2009 11:43AM fulloflife wrote: I have never heard of it and so I looked it up---I found a very good website www.en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phyllodes_tumor   I hope this helps you---to quickly let you know, depending on histology it can be either benign or malignant----we'll all be praying for you
Posts.Title: Phyllodes Tumor mnlfreedom alleynei

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2009 07:20AM fulloflife wrote: I would like to make a correction that was pointed out by Beesie when she stated 'sentinel node does not mean metastatic node from primary site' ----Beesie was correcting me and she is right----I made a one time statement in my original post saying 'sentinel node usually means a metastatic node from the primary site'  that caused all the emotions---and I am truly sorry-----the sentinel node is the group of first nodes that IF cancer cells were to migrate, that's where they would migrate to--it does not mean if cancer is found in the breast that it has metastatized to the sentinal node---my terminology in describing the node was wrong, I understood the words 'metastatic node' as meaning a node capable of recieving cancer cells from the primary site but that's not the true definition of the words 'metastatic node'-------I didn't want to revive this post but I decided to add to it in case someone in the future chooses to read it and the posting creates unnecessary fears and anxiety about their pathology reports and procedures and also feelings of anger and resentment when we all are here to support one another through very difficult experiences----once again Beesie and AnnNYC, I am sorry for being responsible for causing such harsh emotions-----another great reason to trust the professionals taking care of us to provide all the answers
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 07:15AM - edited Apr 10, 2009 07:35AM by fulloflife This is where qualified to interpret data becomes necessary----'cancer-containing area' is the primary site----draining into the first lymph node is the secondary site reason it is called a metastatic node--it does not mean that cancer has spread to the sentinal lymph node but whereever cancer cells move to from the primary site it is called metastatic----to clarify you can have a negative sentinel lymph node biopsy but it is still called a metastatic node because that is the node where cancer cells migrate to--please if you want to ease your minds and get a better understanding ask your doctor, don't negate with me----negating on this site about how to interpret data was the whole reason for my post in the first place----ASK the doctor instead of taking my or your own interpretations-------'claiming that it means' shows no-one is getting it----I'm not claiming anything other than the fact you need to get the clarifacations from your doctor because you're misinterpreting the terminology
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: fulloflife wrote: If a doctor or radiologist attempts to explain the pathology report and it still isn't understood, I would ask them to explain it again. Also I would get the name and phone number of the place where they send the specimen and ask if you could speak to someone who could define the terminology used in the report. if you ask generalized questions that don't pertain to your actual report, they should be able to answer-----getting information from the professionals that are trained to interpret the data is better than trying to figure it all out for ourselves Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 02:03PM - edited Apr 9, 2009 02:07PM by fulloflife out of a medical dictionary-----sentinal node means 'signal' node signal node (quoting dictionary)----'enlargement of one of the supraclavicular lymph nodes. Usually indicative of primary carcinoma of thoracic or abdominal organs' The lymph nodes in the breast are located in the thoracic region. I wouldn't have posted it if my source was unreliable. That's why ALL need to get the information from their doctors because many who aren't qualified to interpret the data are trying to make sense of it---and THAT IS what does more harm than good.
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2009 07:32PM - edited Apr 9, 2009 07:51PM by fulloflife I apologize to all of you---I had no intention of offending anyone---my original post didn't even have anything to do with sentinel nodes---I used the words 'usually means a metastatic node from primary site' and beesie used the words 'a sentinel node is the very first lymph node to receive drainage from a cancer-containing area of the breast'---that defines a metastatic node, it's just worded differently----unfortunately, the intention of my post backfired---the intention of my post was to point out how people on this site are searching and searching for answers in how to interpret their medical reports when the only ones able to do so are the professionals taking care of them, they are the only ones with the answers they are looking for----there is all kinds of information on the internet and if one isn't trained to interpret the data then it can't be interpreted correctly----and yes beesie that includes me and yes annNYC my medical dictionary is old------I have learned from all of you and changed my original post
Posts.Title: suggestion when confronted with confusing path reports fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 10:49AM fulloflife wrote: I recently had a sonogram where the radiologist looked diligently for a 'possible mass' associated with a pathology report that saw a papilloma the size of less than 0.1mm---the pathologist suggested it 'may be associated with a larger lesion further testing is recommended'---the radiologist couldn't find anything----despite the sonogram results, I noticed when I raise my right arm a deep indentation at the base of my breast occurs (only when I raise my arm)---this is a month after a SNC biopsy-----I asked the person doing the sonogram if scar tissue would interfere with the picture and she said scar tissue does not show up on a sonogram-----somewhere you'd think there would be a list as to all things that don't show up on sonograms-----something is causing the indentation in my breast good luck to you
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 11:11AM - edited May 1, 2009 11:15AM by fulloflife I seached the internet in regards to inaccurate sonogram results and found something of interest http://radiology.rsnajnis.org/cgi/content/full/223/2/581-a
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: May 1, 2009 07:48AM fulloflife wrote: faith42---I had a sonogram a couple of weeks after the biopsy results ( because a papilloma was noted by the pathologist)---all results were benign, thank god----but the radiologist that did the biopsy came into the room during the sonogram because she wanted to continue to 'search' for what the pathologists stated could 'possibly' be there but she didn't find a thing-----but what the radiologist did see was a fluid build up along my chest wall and told me that is what is causing my discomfort and is the result of her injecting fluid into my breast to obtain the biopsy-----the sonogram was done about a month after the biopsy, why it hasn't dissipated I don't know----when the probe was pressed into my breast it hurt------lifting my right arm results in the indentation at the base of my breast so I assumed my muscle is pulling on something causing it-----should I tell the radiologist who did the procedure or should I go to my GYN?---it concerns me that the radiologist caused it
Posts.Title: permanent deformity after SCN biopsy fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: fulloflife wrote: First, before I start, I'd like eliminate the fears of those about to undergo the procedure that this isn't something that happens frequently or maybe not at all----except it has happened to me. I had the procedure done while sitting in a chair and they entered a 9-guage needle into the top of my right breast, after the procedure about 20 minutes of compression was needed to stop the bleeding----the next day, I didn't notice any bruising at the entry site but I did notice a black spot at the base of my breast about half the size of a pocket calendar----it eventually went away with some discoloration still present----but what I noticed yesterday was that when I raise my right arm, there is a deep dimpling at the base of my breast where the black mark was (I  assumed the black mark which eventually became lighter was from a pooling of blood inside my breast because of gravity--it never hurt like a bruise)----now I'm beginning to think that during the procedure they had actually punctured my muscle---I received 35cc of Lidocaine which all my doctors including the radiologist said was 'allot' and towards the end of the procedure, the last puncture of the needle was felt as if no lidocaine was given and they went directly into a nerve------the deep dimple is only visible when I raise my arm, looking like a chunk of something was taken out-----has anyone else experienced this deformity after a stereotactic needle core biopsy? Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: permanent deformity after SCN biopsy fulloflife fulloflife

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2009 04:52PM fulloflife wrote: I have always had fibrocystic lumps and through the years never even had a mammogram ordered by my GYN. Before you start thinking my GYN is a bad doctor----I always asked him about lumps noted by me and by him during exam, how he tells the difference---he said that cancerous lumps don't hurt, fibrocystic lumps do. Every lump ever felt was tender. I also drink allot of coffee which years ago they wanted all to sustain from before a mammography. They don't adhere to that rule anymore. But coffee does cause benign lumps in the breasts.. Many doctors react aggressively to what is noted by tests and others do not---also many doctors have fear of getting sued if they misdiagnose something as not being cancer----so a mastectomy would be an aggressive approach to avoid being wrong too late. There is a new diagnostic test someone on this site mentioned that I think you should look into---it's called BSGI ( Breast Specific Gamma Imaging).  If you go the manufactures website ---www.dilontechnologies.com    you can find out if they use it in your area. There are only a few around the country. It's an xray that is so accurate it can distinquish suspicious calcifications from normal cellular activity and prevents many unnecessary biopsies.
Posts.Title: New Lump/s previous LCIS taraleec fulloflife

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 03:27PM fulloflife wrote: Clusters of calcifications are the trigger that radiologists look for in mammograms. But it was recommended to me to have the radiologist do a stereotactic core needle biopsy rather than go to a breast surgeon because the breast surgeon would do a more aggressive biopsy. They said if I had a lump the breast surgeon consultation would be advisable. But for micro-calcifications a stereostatic core needle biopsy is the way to go---if it comes back positive then follow up with a breast surgeon.
Posts.Title: Breast Calcifications azcamm Makratz

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 09:49AM fulloflife wrote: thank you everyone---I made the appt. for the biopsy. Earliest I could get is in a month, but now that I've made the appt. I have put my negative thoughts aside. Actually I've buried them. I'm one of those people that contemplates absolutely everything before making a decision but once I make the decision I don't back track. As they say 'the only thing to fear is fear itself'.  The only time I have ever had a procedure done was when I had a tonselectomy  while in grade school. I've never been on medication, not even tylenol or aspirin. And I've never experienced pregnancy----found out while in my 50s that I had blocked follopian tubes from scar tissue caused by ruptured ovarian cysts.  Never being pregnant put's me on the risk list for breast cancer but generally I'm in good health and eat the right food sources. I don't even eat cold cuts so having a titanium chip and scar tissue inside my breast concerned me----but it must be done to confirm what the cells are and I've accepted that.
Posts.Title: micro calification Edelenbos fulloflife

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2009 03:38PM fulloflife wrote: Leaf, if micro-calcifications are a sign of early cancer are you saying that it could have been there for 4-10 years before the detection of the calicifications? I'm trying to find a needed push to go for a stereotactic core needle biopsy--I haven't made the appt. yet after my radiologist recommended it last week. My six month follow up mammo showed no change in my micro-calcifications and after reading many posts about possible after affects from the biopsy I'm hoping just having follow up digital mammos would be enough. I read about damage to nerves, hematomas, scar tissue, etc....my blood vessels are visible beneath the skin now, I'm sure I'll be one of those people with a hemotoma and my breasts are very sensitive and the needle is supposed to go to the center of my breast to reach the site, then I've read about the computer miscalculating the exact spot the biopsy supposed to be taken from---and if negative the titanium chip the size of only 3mm will inside my breast for maybe another 20 years attached to what? my aging cells? How does it stay put during the changing breast tissue through the years. I once went to a dr that wanted to do a biopsy on my arm because he thought it was possible skin cancer---he charged $200 for the 10 minute office visit---when I left his office I never went back to him again---what was on my arm was normal aging skin and I saved myself from an unnecessary biopsy---I think healthcare has become a big money making industry and I just don't trust it all
Posts.Title: micro calification Edelenbos fulloflife

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 02:55PM fulloflife wrote: I'm glad to have read your postings and happy for your results Jodie. I too have dense breasts and after my first mammography many years ago, I was reluctant to have another one because of the archaic machine they use. My first experience I thought my breast was going to come off and shoot across the room. I was hoping they would have come up with a better machine than the 'pannini maker' by now. But 6 months ago I agreed to have my second mammography and the results were the cluster of microcalcifications that radiologists look for. She recommended I have a stereotactic core needle biopsy done. I hesitated and instead agreed to have a 6 month follow up. This week had it done and the microcalcifications showed no change on the digital mammography. She is still recommending I have the biopsy under digital xray. I've read that 80% of such biopsys come back negative. The titanium chip remaining is also a concern of mine. I've never heard of BSGI. What does that stand for? It sounds as though you didn't need the biopsy after that test. I'm wondering if I could avoid the biopsy if I had that test.   And you are in my prayers too nancy
Posts.Title: BSGI Testing and Calcifications 41jq pcharlene

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 10:07AM fulloflife wrote: Jodi, thank you so much. I found THE website for BSGI. The diagnostic machine is manufactured by Dilon Technologies and their website provides all the information about it and where in the country they have sold it to. I'm in NY and Beth Isreal is the only place that has it and they're not taking any more patients. Cornell Medical Center and some place in Brooklyn also uses it but that's it for NY. Sloan and Kettering doesn't even have it. On the Dilon website they provide contact information to the sales representatives for each area and I called the person closest to me on the cell number they provided and she told me where each machine was located. Everyone should go to their website to find out if a machine is in their area because this diagnostic tool would prevent many unnecessary biopsies. I didn't write down their website location but if one types in Dilon Technologies BSGI in the search word you shouldn't have a problem finding it. Unfortunately, even knowing this technology exists I'll have to go for the biopsy, because it's not available to me.
Posts.Title: BSGI Testing and Calcifications 41jq pcharlene

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2009 10:43AM fulloflife wrote: only one node was positive for metastatic carcinoma-----both statements say the same thing----one out of one node positive for metastatic carcinoma is the first statement----the second statement describes that the 'axillary contents' tissue sample consisted of 7 nodes but only one out of the seven were positive for metastatic carcinoma
